1.Q: What does hurricane formation mainly depend on?
1.A: Warm water mixing with cold water in the ocean
1.B: Warm and cold fronts mixing in the air
1.IncorrectFeedback: Try thinking about where hurricanes usually form in the ocean
1.CorrectFeedback: Warm ocean temperatures provides energy for hurricane formation

2.Q: What is the most dangerous aspect of hurricanes if you live near the coast?
2.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: this factor also causes the most damage for coastal communities
2.CorrectFeedback: The storm surge threatens coastal areas with severe flooding

3.Q: What is the minimum windspeed needed for a storm to be considered a hurricane?
3.IncorrectFeedback: Think about the minimum windspeed a hurricane must hold
3.CorrectFeedback: Hurricanes are classified as having 74+ mph winds

4.Q: What is the difference between hurricanes and cyclones?
4.A: Nothing, they are different names for the same weather phenomenon
4.B: Hurricanes form around the equator while cyclones form at higher latitudes
4.C: Hurricanes have faster windspeeds than cyclones
4.D: Cyclones only have windspeeds of less than 100 mph
4.IncorrectFeedback: Can you think of any differences?
4.CorrectFeedback: The different terms are used depending on where the storm formed

5.Q: When does a tropical storm become a hurricane?
5.A: When the waves carried by the hurricane reach 2 meters in height
5.C: When its sustained windspeed reaches or exceeds 74 mph
5.D: When the atmospheric pressure of the storm drops below 1000 milibars
5.IncorrectFeedback: What is the deciding factor meteorologists use to classify these storms?
5.CorrectFeedback: The cutoff between hurricane and tropical storm occurs at 74 mph

6.Q: Which quadrant(s) of hurricanes, if any, typically have the fastest windspeeds?
6.A: All quadrants typically have similar windspeeds
6.B: The front half of the storm
6.IncorrectFeedback: One quadrant of hurricanes usually has higher windspeeds
6.CorrectFeedback: The forward motion of the entire storm adds to the windspeed in the forward right quadrant

7.Q: What is the safest place within your home to shelter during a hurricane?
7.A: Away from windows, in the basement if possible
7.B: On the uppermost floor, to avoid flooding
7.C: On the roof, so that rescuers can see you
7.D: Under a sturdy piece of furniture
7.IncorrectFeedback: Consider that windspeeds are the biggest danger for most homes
7.CorrectFeedback: Being near a window may cause injury if it breaks. Being away from openings in your home shelters you somewhat

8.Q: How deep does moving water have to be to sweep a grown adult off their feet?
8.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: It does not take much moving water to carry away large objects
8.CorrectFeedback: An adult human can be carried away by as little as 6 inches of fast-moving water!

9.Q: How deep does moving water have to be to sweep away an average car?
9.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: It does not take much moving water to carry away large objects
9.CorrectFeedback: Average cars start being swept away with around 18 inches of moving water. Trucks and SUVs do not fare much better

10.Q: If you are stuck in a flooded area trying to evacuate, what do you do?
10.B: Take your car and drive slowly through the water to a safer location
10.C: Find something to use as a raft and float to a less flooded area
10.D: Move to the highest ground possible and wait to be rescued
10.IncorrectFeedback: Do not try crossing flood waters, it can easily sweep you or your car away
10.CorrectFeedback: The safest move when stuck in a flooded area is to get to high ground and wait, rescue crews will be coming.

11.Q: What is not a danger associated with hurricanes events?
11.B: Damaged power lines and building infrastructure
11.D: Objects being carried by fast winds
11.IncorrectFeedback: This is one of the dangers posed during hurricane events
11.CorrectFeedback: High temperatures are not necessarily associated with hurricanes, unless damaged power lines or electronics starts a fire

12.Q: You are driving to evacuate from a hurricane, and see a barricade blocking your fastest exit path. What do you do?
12.A: Drive around it, because time is the highest priority
12.C: Leave your car to see why the road is barricaded
12.D: Leave your car and keep going down the road by foot
12.IncorrectFeedback: If the road is barricaded, it is probably by local responders to block off flooded areas
12.CorrectFeedback: Even though the road may be the fastest evacuation path, if it is barricaded then the road was likely deemed unsafe to traverse

13.Q: Floodwater is rising in your home and you cannot exit. Where in the building do you go?
13.A: To the attic, because it is the highest point
13.B: To a window, because if you open the window it will let out some water
13.D: A, B, or C would be viable options
13.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Your attic may trap you in rising water, and the water level outside your house is the same as inside
13.CorrectFeedback: The highest full floor is the best place to stay out rising floodwaters

14.Q: Your car is trapped in moving floodwater. What do you do?
14.A: Open the door and exit the car immediately
14.B: Honk your horn to attract attention from possible rescuers
14.C: Try driving your car to a less flooded area
14.IncorrectFeedback: You need to take immediate action, but avoid the floodwaters that can easily carry you away
14.CorrectFeedback: Staying inside the car is the safest action. If the car is filling with water, get on top of the car's roof

15.Q: How much water does a typical hurricane drop on a region?
15.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Not every hurricane floods a region, consider all hurricanes
15.CorrectFeedback: An average hurricane will drop around 6-12 inches of rain over an area

16.Q: What part of a hurricane has the strongest wind and rain?
16.A: The cloud bands around the eye of the hurricane
16.B: The cloud bands at the front edge of the hurricane that hit land first
16.C: The cloud bands at the back edge of the hurricane
16.D: Inside the eye of the hurricane
16.IncorrectFeedback: Consider at which part of the hurricane are the clouds bands the densest
16.CorrectFeedback: The clouds around the eye of the storm will carry the fastest winds and heaviest rains

17.Q: How are hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico affected during El nino years?
17.A: The warmer ocean temperatures in the eastern Pacific have no affect on hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean
17.B: There are more hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico
17.C: There are less hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico
17.D: There are less hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean but more in the Gulf of Mexico
17.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Although ocean temperatures are warmer in the eastern Pacific, wind patterns over the Atlantic are changed during El nino
17.CorrectFeedback: There are actually less hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico during El nino due to increased vertical wind shear weakening hurricane formation

18.Q: What surface ocean temperature (in Fahrenheit) is required for hurricane development?
18.IncorrectFeedback: A lower surface ocean temperature can help hurricanes form
18.CorrectFeedback: At around 80 degrees Fahrenheit surface ocean temperatures can feed hurricanes energy

19.Q: How many tropical storms develop over the Atlantic Ocean during a typical hurricane season?
19.IncorrectFeedback: Consider how many tropical storm events you hear about during an average hurricane season
19.CorrectFeedback: Around 10 tropical storms will develop over the Atlantic Ocean, including the Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico

20.Q: If your area is within the outer reaches of the predicted hurricane path, is it reasonable to assume you are safe?
20.A: Yes, because weather stations have become accurate in tracking and predicting hurricane paths
20.B: No, because many factors affect hurricane path, and your area is within the possible range of the hurricanes path
20.C: Yes, because even if the hurricane follows the outer edge of the predicted path, it will not cause too much damage
20.D: Both A and C are correct
20.IncorrectFeedback: If your area is within any part of the hurricane path range by the weather station, do not assume you will not get hit
20.CorrectFeedback: Many factors influence hurricane paths, so be prepared for the worst
